title-group.article-title: Detection and identification of first and second heart sounds using empirical mode decomposition

abstract.p: We present a novel, low complexity method for the detection of the first and second of heart sounds (S1 and S2, respectively) and the periods of systole and diastole without using an electrocardiogram reference. The algorithm uses a technique called empirical mode decomposition to produce intensity envelopes of the main heart sounds in the time domain. The performance of the algorithm was evaluated using 14,000 cardiac periods from 100 normal and abnormal digital phonocardiographic recordings. The sensitivity of the detection method was 88.3% for both S1 and S2, and the precision (positive predictive value) was 95.8% for both S1 and S2.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many cardiovascular conditions cause murmurs or other heart sound abnormalities.1 Although electrocardiographic (ECG) and echocardiographic studies are widely used in cardiovascular diagnosis, the timeless art of cardiac auscultation remains an important skill in detecting a number of forms of cardiac disease. However, cardiac diagnosis is seldom made based on auscultation alone, as auscultation is innately subjective and depends highly on the skills of the clinician. Consequently, the availability of a simple, objective digital phonocardiographic method that can be used before a patient is sent to a cardiologist for further work-up could be particularly valuable.

During auscultation, the clinician tries to analyze the heart sound components separately and then integrate the information into a preliminary diagnosis. In this process, some important cardiac cycle components to be identified include the first heart sound (Sl), the systolic period, the second heart sound (S2), and the diastolic period. Other important features to be considered include the overall cardiac rhythm, the relative intensity of the heart sound components, the degree of splitting of S2, and the presence and character of murmurs or other extra sounds. However, it can be difficult to systematically consider these factors from mere listening. Consequently, the availability of quantitative methods of phonocardiographic assessment would be expected to be helpful to clinicians. In particular, a means to reliably determine whether a murmur occurs during systole or diastole would be valuable, since all diastolic murmurs are pathologic but not all systolic murmurs are the result of disease.

Heart sound segmentation algorithms found in the literature may be broadly classified into two approaches: those that require an ECG reference as a basis for cardiac cycle segmentation and those that do not. The ECG-free approach may be further divided into supervised and unsupervised methods. In the ECG approach, the QRS complex and the T-wave are detected in order to assist in the identification of the S1 and S2 segments, respectively.2 With low-quality ECG signals, the T-waves may not always be clearly visible; in such cases, S2 may sometimes be identified using an unsupervised classifier.3 In order to avoid extra instrumentation and an extra channel of data acquisition, a number of researchers have attempted to identify S1 and S2 without using an ECG reference. Several supervised techniques have been suggested for this, such as artificial neural networks4 and decision trees.5 Other approaches involve unsupervised techniques such as use of an envelogram,6 spectrogram quantization methods,7 and self-organizing maps using the Mel frequency cepstrum coefficients.8 In practice, these methods may not perform well for some types of heart sounds (e.g. severe murmur cases and sounds produced by prosthetic heart valves). Additionally, some of these methods suffer from the disadvantage that they require that the signal be transformed into the frequency domain for further processing, a computationally intensive process. Finally, some frequency-domain methods may suffer in performance when there is overlap in frequency ranges for the baseline signal (e.g. heart sounds) and any contaminating noise (e.g. heart murmurs). Operating in the time domain, our proposed method—the use of empirical mode decomposition (EMD)—eliminates some of these concerns. It is adaptive, computationally efficient, and, since is based on the local characteristic time scale of the data, it can be applied to nonstationary signals. Several recent studies support the use of this method.9–12

In this article, a novel method of detection of S1 and S2 is described, which does not rely on an ECG reference or other prior clinical information. In the algorithm, the phonocardiogram (PCG) signal is decomposed into specific functions called intrinsic mode functions (IMFs) using a technique called EMD. The algorithm works as follows: First, the heart sounds are segmented into sound lobes using the envelope of IMFs of the EMD decomposed signal. Then, S1 and S2 in each heart cycle are classified by inspecting the nearest interval between two sound segments to the estimated systolic interval (duration of S1–S2). Here, the identification is based on the following facts: (a) the longest time interval between two adjacent peaks in the recording is the diastolic period (from the end of S2 to the beginning of S1) and (b) the duration of the systolic period (from the end of S1 to the beginning of S2) is relatively constant compared to the diastolic period. After the longest time interval is found, the start and the end marks of that interval are set as S2 and S1, respectively. Then, the forward and backward intervals from the longest interval onward are checked.6–8,13–19

The systolic interval starts at the beginning of S1 and lasts until the beginning of S2. The diastolic interval starts at the beginning of S2 and lasts until the end of the cycle.13 The S1 is, in part, the result of closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves. A short time after the onset of S1, aortic and pulmonary valves start opening, and the ventricular blood ejects into the systemic and pulmonary arteries.13 The blood ejection lasts until the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves.13 This period of time is called the ejection time (ET), and the part of the systolic duration before the ET is named the pre-ejection period (PEP). Respiration has significant influences on right ventricular size, diastolic filling time, and also heart rate, especially in children.14,15

The influences of respiration on the left ventricular dimension and filling time are the same as for the right ventricle in children.16 The effect of respiration on diastolic filling time and heart rate is age dependent.16 On the other hand, the influence of respiration on the ET is in the opposite direction with respect to the PEP.17 Therefore, the whole systolic time, which is the sum of PEP and ET, remains almost constant. This is in contrast with the diastolic period, which has tangible variations due to respiration, and it is also longer than the duration of systole.17 These are helpful clues in order to define the interval between two sound segments as belonging to a systolic or diastolic period. We present our results as a series of seven sample cases.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: We collected the heart sounds from children at the Pediatric Clinic of Modares Hospital in Tehran between 2010 and 2011. In all cases, the operator recorded the acoustic signal from the upper anterior chest wall, picking the area with the loudest amplitude signal. Data were collected from a total of 100 cases, including 8 normal cases, with an age range of 1–26 years. Written informed consent was obtained; copies are available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal. The patients (except for the normal controls) had a history of heart murmur, which included 30 with a ventricular septal defect (VSD), 12 with an atrial septal defect (ASD), 6 with both ASD and VSD, 12 with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), 6 with pulmonary stenosis (PS), and 34 with other pathology. In all cases, the diagnosis was confirmed by echocardiography. A summary of findings for some of the cases is presented in Table 1.

sec.title: Preprocessing
sec.p: Heart sound signals recorded by electronic stethoscopes are often encompassed with high-frequency noise; hence, preprocessing is essential.18–20 The signals were filtered to eliminate the noise followed by normalization and segmentation. These steps were illustrated in the following.

sec.title: Filtering
sec.p: Since heart sound signals are mainly less than 800 Hz, a second-order Butterworth low-pass filter with a −3-dB passband gain as the minimum and cutoff frequency of 800 Hz was designed by digital finite impulse response (FIR) methods.20 The Butterworth filter is a type of signal processing filter designed to have as flat a frequency response as possible in the passband. It is also referred to as a maximally flat magnitude filter.

sec.title: Down sampling
sec.p: The original sampling rate by Gold Wave software was set to 44,100 Hz. In order to decrease the processing time and in accordance with the Nyquist theorem, the PCG signal was resampled by retaining every 10th sample.

sec.title: EMD
sec.p: Our approach to separate the main heart sounds from murmurs uses EMD. EMD is defined by a process called sifting, and it decomposes any data into a set of IMF components, which become the basis functions for representing the data.21 It is well known that the IMF basis functions provide a physically meaningful representation of the underlying processes in many applications.9–12,22 For our S1 and S2 detection application, we only use a subset of the EMD algorithm, that is, only the portion of the EMD algorithm that determines the fifth IMF (IMF 5). Specifically, given a signal x(t), the IMF 5 was found via the EMD by the following procedure.

The heart sound signal was first decomposed to IMFs. To acquire the IMFs, local minima and maxima of the signal are determined. The EMD method makes the signal more symmetrical by eliminating the riding waves and decomposes the signal adaptively. In this study, IMF 5 was chosen after comparing it with other possibilities. From Figure 2, it can be seen that the first, second, third, and fourth IMFs do a poor job of summarizing the recorded PCG signal, while the IMF 5 does a satisfactory job.24 This was the basis for choosing IMF 5 for our study. We additionally confirmed the choice of IMF 5 by numerical means. Here, fast Fourier transforms (FFTs) of IMF 1 through 5 were calculated in order to find out the range of frequency of each and compare it with the original signal. The range of frequencies in IMF 5 corresponded with those of the main heart sounds needed for subsequent procedures. The extracted IMF 5 and its absolute value are shown in Figure 3.

sec.title: Segmentation
sec.p: In this section, the heart sound signals are segmented into cycles. Four items are recognized during this step: the first heart sound (S1), the second heart sound (S2), the systolic period, and the diastolic period. To detect these terms with noise interference rejection, the Shannon energy (SE) of IMF 5 was used and calculated as follows6,25–28

As shown in equation (5), the feature of SE was to suppress the low-amplitude components of the signal.6 It attenuates the effects of low value noise and makes the low intensity sounds easier to find. The main components, S1 and S2, would therefore be picked up. Compared with other algorithms, such as absolute value or Shannon entropy, SE is expected to be better for segmenting noisy heart sound signals.6 The SE of the IMF 5 and its envelope are calculated and plotted in Figure 4.

sec.p: The threshold value for sound detection was initially set to 98% of the entire signal average value. If the threshold is chosen higher than 98%, some S2 sounds with a lower peak will be excluded and missed. But for thresholds lower than 98%, noise, murmurs, or additional heart sound can adversely affect the results of S1 and S2 recognition. Nevertheless, higher thresholds can be acceptable when it would be easier to reidentify the missing S2 than deal with noise-related problems. In particular, because S2 usually has a smaller amplitude than S1, the probability of missing this sound during the threshold setting process is higher. In such a case, if S2 is missed, a recovery procedure must be applied in order to identify S2 again.
S1 and S2 were recognized by three steps as follows:28

list-item.p: If two peaks higher than the threshold were detected within 50 ms, the one with lower energy was eliminated from consideration.

For every interval between peaks, a comparison was applied with the next interval, and their ratio was calculated. The range of variation of this ratio was established. The shorter length intervals were considered to be systolic periods, while the longer length intervals were considered to be diastolic periods.
For the intervals that could not be assigned to systole or diastole, a secondary threshold was set to find S1 or S2, which would not otherwise have been recognized.

sec.p: These steps were applied to ensure that S1 and S2 could be picked out correctly. Systolic and diastolic periods were then recognized. An iterative recognition method was then applied for detecting missing components. The iterative recognition method examined whether the detected points were occurring periodically. For those positions where S1 or S2 should have been detected, the method determined whether there is a missing point. The algorithm calculates the distances between the peaks continuously and compares it to the previous one to check whether the top of S2 is missed. If the top of S2 is missed, then the model rebuilds it based on S1. The detected S1 and S2 sounds are shown in Figure 5.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Heart sound records collected from patients at Modares Hospital in Tehran were used to verify the recognition accuracy of the proposed method. The efficiency of our proposed method was evaluated by 100 records of this database. sec.p: The overall performance of the algorithm was evaluated using sensitivity and precision performance metrics. The detected and missed components were denoted as true positive (TP) and false negative (FN). The sensitivity and precision (also known as positive predictive value) of the method were calculated as follows
The sensitivity of the detection method applied to 100 patients in the database was 88.3% for both S1 and S2, and the precision was 95.8% for both S1 and S2.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The aim of this research was to automatically recognize S1 and S2 in normal and abnormal PCGs. The signals were adaptively decomposed to IMFs. This method provides information about the heart sound signal by keeping the signal in the time domain, unlike methods where the signal needs to be transformed to the frequency domain, a process which is computationally intensive. Using the proposed method, the sensitivity for S1 and S2 was 88.3% and the precision was 95.8%. This is the highest precision over the other methods that we have been able to achieve with our proposed algorithm. With the adaptive method based on time-domain analysis, the algorithm helped eliminate the influence of noise and body movement artifacts. The effects of high-energy murmurs appear to be eliminated, while other methods like wavelet28 and homomorphic filtering29 are not able to perform as well. In some cases with severe murmurs as in cases of VSD or TOF, these methods fail to detect the main heart sounds. Thus, automated recognition of S1 and S2 using our method appears to be feasible.

Regardless, the existence of extra sounds during the systolic and diastolic periods, such as murmurs or noise produced from the electronic stethoscope, as well as the presence of low-amplitude heart sounds, can still contribute to misclassifications. Interference from noise can be reduced by the proposed method when the noise and murmur are no larger than S1 and S2. Low amplitude signals can sometimes make S1 and S2 indistinguishable from background noise; since the signal amplitude depends on the stethoscope position on the patient’s chest, positioning of the stethoscope is very important. Low amplitude signals increase the difficulties for clinicians to carry out auscultation. Some recent studies have also evaluated the relationship between the level of physician experience and accurate auscultation of heart sound.30

Heart sound analysis has also been incorporated into acoustic cardiography, which combines ECG and sound information to diagnose cardiac conditions.31 The method we propose may be potentially helpful for the early detection of some heart diseases, such as left ventricular dysfunction, congenital heart conditions, or myocardial ischemia. Several time-frequency methods have also been developed for systolic and diastolic heart sound analysis in recent years.27 In comparison with previous detection methods, our method is adaptive for nonstationary heart sound signals.

One reason for the occasional incorrect identification of S1 and S2 was high-level interfering signals like speech, crying, or other ambient noises, which overlap with heart sounds in character. However, the algorithm presented here appears to be insensitive to respiration effects, the frequency band for airflow sounds in the respiratory system being about 30–40 Hz in our experience. As these usually cannot be avoided in recordings from children and infants, this is a benefit of the algorithm compared to the previous one used in our work. We also noted that any sudden release of the stethoscope from the patients can also result in incorrect results; this can be avoided by paying close attention to the recording technique.

Finally, it is important to emphasize some of the limitations of our study. First, the method has not been assessed by comparison against trained humans such as physiologists or cardiologists, nor has the method undergone a formal comparison against other automated techniques using an extensive dataset. Consequently, there is no guarantee that the proposed technique will be consistently superior in performance to existing methods.

Second, while it is our experience that time-domain methods such as ours take less time than FFT-based methods, the present study did not collect computation time statistics. (Additionally, FFTs can now be performed inexpensively in hardware anyway.)

Finally, much work remains to be done to systematically explore the performance of the method in estimating the timing of the onset of S1 and S2 under various conditions; our analysis here focused only on detecting (recognizing) these sounds and not on characterizing their timing. That being said, we expect that the importance of the present method may not so much be in determining the timing of the onset of the first heart sound as in proving a simple means to establish an “analysis window,” whereby the characteristics of the first heart sound can be studied (e.g. to test our unpublished hypothesis that the amplitude and the spectral characteristics of S1 vary over the respiratory cycle in hypovolemic patients undergoing positive pressure ventilation).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The presented automatic segmentation algorithm using EMD to extract suitable IMFs for envelope calculations has been found to be effective to segment PCG signals into four parts. The algorithm has shown over 90% success in 100 recordings with different kinds of murmurs, which include 14,000 cycles of heart sounds. This is a good basis for further analysis of the heart sound signals.
